In looking at all the evidence here, I think there is a most likely scenario. We don't know who initiated all these contacts, but it was probably the Russians. After all, that's what ambassadors do -- they seek influence in the host country by meeting with important people.

Apparently, the Russians decided to meet often with Trump people and seldom, if ever, with Hillary people. While that may be because of the attitudes of the two candidates, the ambassador would not likely turn down a meeting with Clinton, who appeared to be a shoo-in. So it was probably Clinton who gave the cold shoulder to the Russians.

That leaves the question of why the Russians met so often with Trump people, when Trump looked like a loser. And the most likely answer is that they were aggressively trying to influence the election and they were looking to the Trump people for information about how they might proceed. From there, I see three possibilities. Either the Russians directed the conversations to helpful subjects while concealing what they were up to; or they were suggestive in their questioning but nobody acknowledged what was going on; or they out and out conspired with the Trump people. The most likely scenario is clearly the second one. and whether anything criminal occurred would likely require a review of the specifics of each and every conversation.

Your scenarios 1 & 2 point to the dangers of having such a preponderance of people in the Trump crowd who appear to be blinded by a single focus on securing maximum personal financial profit (with little apparent regard for any human costs in adopting such a strategy) and by their apparent total ineptness and incompetence at anything other than securing "deals" that benefit themselves.  Such people are both unlikely to notice (or, if they do, to care) if those they're interacting with are benefiting in ways potentially damaging to others, including the people of the U.S..    They appear to be precisely the kind of people that Campaigner Trump derided and demonized as being responsible for the loss of US manufacturing jobs and the failure to pay US taxes and this campaign stance appears to have been a principal reason for his election victory.  Has an electorate ever been so clearly duped?

There's only one reason why Clinton didn't meet with Russia, because the Republicans would've jumped all over her and brought up the atrocious uranium deal the Clintons made  with Russia through their Canadian partner. Just one more reason amongst many, why Clinton never would have won the election.
So why lie about the meetings?

Trump is on the record as saying that he hasn't called the Russians in the last ten years, even though his Miss Universe contest was staged in Moscow three years ago. Even though he was previously on the record as saying that, in the context of that contest, he had spoken with the highest officials of the Russian government and they were very nice to him. Couldn't have been nicer.

If everything was innocent between Trump, the Trumpsters and Moscow, no need to hide from it. And, Sessions, no need to forget your contacts when you were both a senator and a participant in the Trump campaign.

Why are there so many leaks about all of this? Because there is so much lying or, at minimum, obfuscating about all of this. Plus, Trump came into DC attacking the intelligence community and, first thing, staging an unrelated appearance at the CIA in front of the Wall of Honor while bragging about the turnout at his inauguration. Bad form. Very.

Certainly, it appears obvious that Trump is being paid back for attacking the well funded intelligence community. It's an old story. The mafia wrote the book on payback, but Trump is writing a new chapter.

Did the Russians steal our election? We don't know, but we do know they tried to an alarming degree and we do know the Trumpsters have not been forthcoming about contacts before, during and after the campaign. Last summer we went to Paris for a week. Having lived there many years prior, out of a mix of practicality and curiosity we downloaded and used UBER for the stay.
With just about each driver, two to four a day, I engaged discussion to attempt to understand the business model that seemingly allowed half price rides as compared to G7, the leading taxi service.
I came away with two key conclusions :
- the business model can only survive IF they run traditional taxi service out of business then increase ride price;
- the driver motivation was either a part time supplemental income, and or for those with time to spare a means of financing the acquisition price of a upscale vehicle.
We were very satisfied by the clean new vehicles and the cashless service but could already faintly hear the driver gripe.
When we got home I deleted the application not so much for the service we enjoyed but the contemptible culture of the company, motivation validated of recent.
There is a difference between disruptive versus destructive technology, in our view UBER is the latter and we will avoid its use in the future.
If you concluded so much based on so little, your conclusions aren't worth the paper you might care to print them on.  Sorry.  Sounding authoritative isn't being authoritative.
